Other information

Solution

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

Reference

 		http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

 		13

Low (Warning) Cookie set without HttpOnly flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Product
Parameter
ASP.NET_SessionId=41rr1ecjeykxs3srob5leiuh; path=/
Attack
Other information

Solution

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

Reference

 		www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

WASC Id

 		13

Low (Warning) Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Product
Parameter
Attack
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

 		https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

WASC Id

 		14

Low (Warning) X-Content-Type-Options header missing

Description

The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Product
Parameter
Attack
Other information

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages. If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

Reference

WASC Id

Low (Warning) Content Security Policy (CSP) Header Not Set

Description

Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks, including Cross Site Scripting (XSS) and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a standard HTTP header that allows website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Product
Parameter
Attack
Other information

Solution

Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to set Content Security Policy headers.

Reference

 		https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Security/CSP/Introducing_Content_Security_Policy https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Content_Security_Policy http://www.w3.org/TR/CSP/ http://w3c.github.io/webappsec/specs/content-security-policy/csp-specification.dev.html http://www.html5rocks.com/en/tutorials/security/content-security-policy/ http://caniuse.com/#feat=contentsecuritypolicy

WASC Id

Low (Warning) Server Leaks Version Information via "Server" HTTP Response Header Field

Description

The web/application server is leaking version information via the "Server" HTTP response header. Access to such information may facilitate attackers identifying other vulnerabilities your web/application server is subject to.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Product
Parameter
Attack
Other information

Solution

Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to suppress the "Server" header or provide generic details.

Reference

 		http://httpd.apache.org/docs/current/mod/core.html#servertokens http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ff648552.aspx#ht_urlscan_007 http://blogs.msdn.com/b/varunm/archive/2013/04/23/remove-unwanted-http-response-headers.aspx http://www.troyhunt.com/2012/02/shhh-dont-let-your-response-headers.html

WASC Id

 		13

Low (Warning) Strict-Transport-Security Header Not Set

Description

HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) is a web security policy mechanism whereby a web server declares that complying user agents (such as a web browser) are to interact with it using only secure HTTPS connections (i.e. HTTP layered over TLS/SSL). HSTS is an IETF standards track protocol and is specified in RFC 6797.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Product
Parameter
Attack
Other information

Solution

Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to enforce Strict-Transport-Security.

Reference

 		https://www.owasp.org/index.php/HTTP_Strict_Transport_Security https://www.owasp.org/index.php/List_of_useful_HTTP_headers http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTTP_Strict_Transport_Security http://caniuse.com/stricttransportsecurity http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6797

WASC Id

Low (Warning) Server Leaks Information via "X-Powered-By" HTTP Response Header Field(s)

Description

The web/application server is leaking information via one or more "X-Powered-By" HTTP response headers. Access to such information may facilitate attackers identifying other frameworks/components your web application is reliant upon and the vulnerabilities such components may be subject to.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Product
Parameter
Attack
Other information

Solution

Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to suppress "X-Powered-By" headers.

Reference

 		http://blogs.msdn.com/b/varunm/archive/2013/04/23/remove-unwanted-http-response-headers.aspx http://www.troyhunt.com/2012/02/shhh-dont-let-your-response-headers.html

WASC Id

 		13

Low (Warning) Incomplete or no cache-control and pragma HTTPHeader set

Description

The cache-control and pragma HTTPHeader have not been set properly allowing the browser and proxies to cache content

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Product/Add
Parameter
private, s-maxage=0
Attack
Other information

Solution

Whenever possible ensure the cache-control HTTPHeader is set with no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate, private, and the pragma HTTPHeader is set with no-cache.

Reference

 		https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Session_Management_Cheat_Sheet#Web_Content_Caching

WASC Id

Low (Warning) Cookie set without secure flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Product/Add
Parameter
ASP.NET_SessionId=oukrjbkrxk3vs13qa2zcaq5w; path=/
Attack
Other information

Solution

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

Reference

 		http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

 		13

Low (Warning) Cookie set without HttpOnly flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Product/Add
Parameter
ASP.NET_SessionId=oukrjbkrxk3vs13qa2zcaq5w; path=/
Attack
Other information

Solution

Reference

 		www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

WASC Id

 		13

Low (Warning) Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Product/Add
Parameter
Attack
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

 		https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

WASC Id

 		14

Low (Warning) X-Content-Type-Options header missing

Description

The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Product/Add
Parameter
Attack
Other information

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages. If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

Reference

Description

These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a standard HTTP header that allows website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.

Parameter

Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to suppress the "Server" header or provide generic details.

Reference

 		http://httpd.apache.org/docs/current/mod/core.html#servertokens http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ff648552.aspx#ht_urlscan_007 http://blogs.msdn.com/b/varunm/archive/2013/04/23/remove-unwanted-http-response-headers.aspx http://www.troyhunt.com/2012/02/shhh-dont-let-your-response-headers.html

WASC Id

 		13

Low (Warning) Strict-Transport-Security Header Not Set

Description

HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) is a web security policy mechanism whereby a web server declares that complying user agents (such as a web browser) are to interact with it using only secure HTTPS connections (i.e. HTTP layered over TLS/SSL). HSTS is an IETF standards track protocol and is specified in RFC 6797.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Product/Search
Parameter
Attack
Other information

Solution

Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to enforce Strict-Transport-Security.

Reference

 		https://www.owasp.org/index.php/HTTP_Strict_Transport_Security https://www.owasp.org/index.php/List_of_useful_HTTP_headers http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTTP_Strict_Transport_Security http://caniuse.com/stricttransportsecurity http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6797

WASC Id

Low (Warning) Server Leaks Information via "X-Powered-By" HTTP Response Header Field(s)

Description

The web/application server is leaking information via one or more "X-Powered-By" HTTP response headers. Access to such information may facilitate attackers identifying other frameworks/components your web application is reliant upon and the vulnerabilities such components may be subject to.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Product/Search
Parameter
Attack
Other information

Solution

Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to suppress "X-Powered-By" headers.

Reference

 		http://blogs.msdn.com/b/varunm/archive/2013/04/23/remove-unwanted-http-response-headers.aspx http://www.troyhunt.com/2012/02/shhh-dont-let-your-response-headers.html

WASC Id

 		13

Low (Warning) X-Content-Type-Options header missing

Description

The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/favicon.ico
Parameter
Attack
Other information

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages. If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

Reference

WASC Id

Low (Warning) Content Security Policy (CSP) Header Not Set

Description

Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks, including Cross Site Scripting (XSS) and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a standard HTTP header that allows website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/favicon.ico
Parameter
Attack
Other information

Solution

Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to set Content Security Policy headers.

Reference

 		https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Security/CSP/Introducing_Content_Security_Policy https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Content_Security_Policy http://www.w3.org/TR/CSP/ http://w3c.github.io/webappsec/specs/content-security-policy/csp-specification.dev.html http://www.html5rocks.com/en/tutorials/security/content-security-policy/ http://caniuse.com/#feat=contentsecuritypolicy

Description

This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Parameter

Other information

WASC Id

 		13

Low (Warning) Incomplete or no cache-control and pragma HTTPHeader set

Description

The cache-control and pragma HTTPHeader have not been set properly allowing the browser and proxies to cache content

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/?Length=7
Parameter
private, s-maxage=0
Attack
Other information

Solution

Whenever possible ensure the cache-control HTTPHeader is set with no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate, private, and the pragma HTTPHeader is set with no-cache.

Reference

 		https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Session_Management_Cheat_Sheet#Web_Content_Caching

WASC Id

Low (Warning) Cookie set without HttpOnly flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/?Length=7
Parameter
ASP.NET_SessionId=wys1y4r5apitdwqgdgrizwwy; path=/
Attack
Other information

Solution

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

Reference

 		www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

WASC Id

 		13

Low (Warning) Cookie set without HttpOnly flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/?Length=7
Parameter
__RequestVerificationToken_L1NxbGlNb2Rlcm5BcHA1=hhHnYIUan6dKGYI40AtlgARNAZsVppsR_apXH1A9oRLgpXmgScaR8zSwKZeWqtuuamdVcr2-7o2iEzSRz_w63x6lgJQCqg8FQ07XvpElA1WvPO3zJg_3LMAV_uFDbCwozyByfXb3FRsNc0bqyah4FA2; path=/
Attack
Other information

Solution

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

Reference

 		www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

WASC Id

 		13

Low (Warning) Cookie set without secure flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/?Length=7
Parameter
ASP.NET_SessionId=wys1y4r5apitdwqgdgrizwwy; path=/
Attack
Other information

Solution

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

Reference

 		http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

 		13

Low (Warning) Cookie set without secure flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/?Length=7
Parameter
__RequestVerificationToken_L1NxbGlNb2Rlcm5BcHA1=hhHnYIUan6dKGYI40AtlgARNAZsVppsR_apXH1A9oRLgpXmgScaR8zSwKZeWqtuuamdVcr2-7o2iEzSRz_w63x6lgJQCqg8FQ07XvpElA1WvPO3zJg_3LMAV_uFDbCwozyByfXb3FRsNc0bqyah4FA2; path=/
Attack
Other information

Solution

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

Reference

 		http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

 		13

Low (Warning) Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/?Length=7
Parameter
Attack
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

 		https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

WASC Id

 		14

Low (Warning) X-Content-Type-Options header missing

Description

The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/?Length=7
Parameter
Attack
Other information

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages. If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

Reference

WASC Id

Low (Warning) Content Security Policy (CSP) Header Not Set

Description

Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks, including Cross Site Scripting (XSS) and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a standard HTTP header that allows website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/?Length=7
Parameter
Attack
Other information

Solution

Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to set Content Security Policy headers.

Reference

 		https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Security/CSP/Introducing_Content_Security_Policy https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Content_Security_Policy http://www.w3.org/TR/CSP/ http://w3c.github.io/webappsec/specs/content-security-policy/csp-specification.dev.html http://www.html5rocks.com/en/tutorials/security/content-security-policy/ http://caniuse.com/#feat=contentsecuritypolicy

WASC Id

Low (Warning) Server Leaks Version Information via "Server" HTTP Response Header Field

Description

The web/application server is leaking version information via the "Server" HTTP response header. Access to such information may facilitate attackers identifying other vulnerabilities your web/application server is subject to.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/?Length=7
Parameter
Attack
Other information

Solution

Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to suppress the "Server" header or provide generic details.

Reference

 		http://httpd.apache.org/docs/current/mod/core.html#servertokens http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ff648552.aspx#ht_urlscan_007 http://blogs.msdn.com/b/varunm/archive/2013/04/23/remove-unwanted-http-response-headers.aspx http://www.troyhunt.com/2012/02/shhh-dont-let-your-response-headers.html

WASC Id

 		13

Low (Warning) Strict-Transport-Security Header Not Set

Description

HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) is a web security policy mechanism whereby a web server declares that complying user agents (such as a web browser) are to interact with it using only secure HTTPS connections (i.e. HTTP layered over TLS/SSL). HSTS is an IETF standards track protocol and is specified in RFC 6797.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/?Length=7
Parameter
Attack
Other information

Solution

Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to enforce Strict-Transport-Security.

Reference

 		https://www.owasp.org/index.php/HTTP_Strict_Transport_Security https://www.owasp.org/index.php/List_of_useful_HTTP_headers http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTTP_Strict_Transport_Security http://caniuse.com/stricttransportsecurity http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6797

WASC Id

Low (Warning) Server Leaks Information via "X-Powered-By" HTTP Response Header Field(s)

Description

The web/application server is leaking information via one or more "X-Powered-By" HTTP response headers. Access to such information may facilitate attackers identifying other frameworks/components your web application is reliant upon and the vulnerabilities such components may be subject to.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/?Length=7
Parameter
Attack
Other information

Solution

Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to suppress "X-Powered-By" headers.

Reference

 		http://blogs.msdn.com/b/varunm/archive/2013/04/23/remove-unwanted-http-response-headers.aspx http://www.troyhunt.com/2012/02/shhh-dont-let-your-response-headers.html

WASC Id

 		13

Low (Warning) Incomplete or no cache-control and pragma HTTPHeader set

Description

The cache-control and pragma HTTPHeader have not been set properly allowing the browser and proxies to cache content

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Home/Add?Length=7
Parameter
private
Attack
Other information

Solution

Whenever possible ensure the cache-control HTTPHeader is set with no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate, private, and the pragma HTTPHeader is set with no-cache.

Reference

 		https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Session_Management_Cheat_Sheet#Web_Content_Caching

WASC Id

Low (Warning) Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Home/Add?Length=7
Parameter
Attack
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

 		https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

WASC Id

 		14

Low (Warning) X-Content-Type-Options header missing

Description

The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Home/Add?Length=7
Parameter
Attack
Other information

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages. If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

Reference

WASC Id

Low (Warning) Content Security Policy (CSP) Header Not Set

Description

Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks, including Cross Site Scripting (XSS) and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a standard HTTP header that allows website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.

https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Home/Add?Length=7

Other information

Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

WASC Id

Low (Warning) Cookie set without HttpOnly flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Secret/Stash
Parameter
ASP.NET_SessionId=l32h22qiquuutumc4aotozd2; path=/
Attack
Other information

Solution

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

Reference

 		www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

WASC Id

 		13

Low (Warning) Cookie set without HttpOnly flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Secret/Stash
Parameter
__RequestVerificationToken_L1NxbGlNb2Rlcm5BcHA1=GdoYys_ge_lHE9-Y3O79yCI5k2S6IASYOwrxJvTIL77AnVH2T2BI_MWj2vCjSgsgAPZzU2O6Qbw6o1yzqO3-s-BEHP7bJyBbdRWLDtLuhGhWBYPXS1b4JoeW_N2YG2GZR8EeX8bG1KpuYt-X2BJbfQ2; path=/
Attack
Other information

Solution

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

Reference

 		www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

WASC Id

 		13

Low (Warning) Cookie set without secure flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Secret/Stash
Parameter
ASP.NET_SessionId=l32h22qiquuutumc4aotozd2; path=/
Attack
Other information

Solution

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

Reference

 		http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

 		13

Low (Warning) Cookie set without secure flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Secret/Stash
Parameter
__RequestVerificationToken_L1NxbGlNb2Rlcm5BcHA1=GdoYys_ge_lHE9-Y3O79yCI5k2S6IASYOwrxJvTIL77AnVH2T2BI_MWj2vCjSgsgAPZzU2O6Qbw6o1yzqO3-s-BEHP7bJyBbdRWLDtLuhGhWBYPXS1b4JoeW_N2YG2GZR8EeX8bG1KpuYt-X2BJbfQ2; path=/
Attack
Other information

Solution

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

Reference

 		http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

 		13

Low (Warning) Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Secret/Stash
Parameter
Attack
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

 		https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

WASC Id

 		14

Low (Warning) X-Content-Type-Options header missing

Description

The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Secret/Stash
Parameter
Attack
Other information

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages. If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

Reference

WASC Id

Low (Warning) Content Security Policy (CSP) Header Not Set

Description

Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks, including Cross Site Scripting (XSS) and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a standard HTTP header that allows website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Secret/Stash
Parameter
Attack
Other information

Solution

Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to set Content Security Policy headers.

Reference

 		https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Security/CSP/Introducing_Content_Security_Policy https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Content_Security_Policy http://www.w3.org/TR/CSP/ http://w3c.github.io/webappsec/specs/content-security-policy/csp-specification.dev.html http://www.html5rocks.com/en/tutorials/security/content-security-policy/ http://caniuse.com/#feat=contentsecuritypolicy

WASC Id

Low (Warning) Server Leaks Version Information via "Server" HTTP Response Header Field

Description

The web/application server is leaking version information via the "Server" HTTP response header. Access to such information may facilitate attackers identifying other vulnerabilities your web/application server is subject to.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Secret/Stash
Parameter
Attack
Other information

Solution

Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to suppress the "Server" header or provide generic details.

Reference

 		http://httpd.apache.org/docs/current/mod/core.html#servertokens http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ff648552.aspx#ht_urlscan_007 http://blogs.msdn.com/b/varunm/archive/2013/04/23/remove-unwanted-http-response-headers.aspx http://www.troyhunt.com/2012/02/shhh-dont-let-your-response-headers.html

WASC Id

 		13

Low (Warning) Strict-Transport-Security Header Not Set

Description

HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) is a web security policy mechanism whereby a web server declares that complying user agents (such as a web browser) are to interact with it using only secure HTTPS connections (i.e. HTTP layered over TLS/SSL). HSTS is an IETF standards track protocol and is specified in RFC 6797.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Secret/Stash
Parameter
Attack
Other information

Solution

Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to enforce Strict-Transport-Security.

Reference

 		https://www.owasp.org/index.php/HTTP_Strict_Transport_Security https://www.owasp.org/index.php/List_of_useful_HTTP_headers http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTTP_Strict_Transport_Security http://caniuse.com/stricttransportsecurity http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6797

WASC Id

Low (Warning) Server Leaks Information via "X-Powered-By" HTTP Response Header Field(s)

Description

The web/application server is leaking information via one or more "X-Powered-By" HTTP response headers. Access to such information may facilitate attackers identifying other frameworks/components your web application is reliant upon and the vulnerabilities such components may be subject to.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Secret/Stash
Parameter
Attack
Other information

Solution

Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to suppress "X-Powered-By" headers.

Reference

 		http://blogs.msdn.com/b/varunm/archive/2013/04/23/remove-unwanted-http-response-headers.aspx http://www.troyhunt.com/2012/02/shhh-dont-let-your-response-headers.html

WASC Id

 		13

Low (Warning) X-Content-Type-Options header missing

Description

The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Images/coolduck.png
Parameter
Attack
Other information

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages. If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

Reference

WASC Id

Low (Warning) Content Security Policy (CSP) Header Not Set

Description

Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks, including Cross Site Scripting (XSS) and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a standard HTTP header that allows website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Images/coolduck.png
Parameter
Attack
Other information

Solution

Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to set Content Security Policy headers.

Reference

 		https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Security/CSP/Introducing_Content_Security_Policy https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Content_Security_Policy http://www.w3.org/TR/CSP/ http://w3c.github.io/webappsec/specs/content-security-policy/csp-specification.dev.html http://www.html5rocks.com/en/tutorials/security/content-security-policy/ http://caniuse.com/#feat=contentsecuritypolicy

 		13

WASC Id

 		13

Low (Warning) Cookie set without secure flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Quack/Now
Parameter
ASP.NET_SessionId=pjqt2pa0mvvrtlqszae1g1kr; path=/
Attack
Other information

Solution

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

Reference

 		http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

 		13

Low (Warning) Cookie set without HttpOnly flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Quack/Now
Parameter
ASP.NET_SessionId=pjqt2pa0mvvrtlqszae1g1kr; path=/
Attack
Other information

Solution

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

Reference

 		www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

WASC Id

 		13

Low (Warning) Incomplete or no cache-control and pragma HTTPHeader set

Description

The cache-control and pragma HTTPHeader have not been set properly allowing the browser and proxies to cache content

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Product?categoryId=8
Parameter
private, s-maxage=0
Attack
Other information

Solution

Whenever possible ensure the cache-control HTTPHeader is set with no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate, private, and the pragma HTTPHeader is set with no-cache.

Reference

 		https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Session_Management_Cheat_Sheet#Web_Content_Caching

WASC Id

Low (Warning) Cookie set without secure flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Product?categoryId=8
Parameter
ASP.NET_SessionId=pjagx2ivv5silfz4tnk1ztfl; path=/
Attack
Other information

Solution

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

Reference

 		http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

 		13

Low (Warning) Cookie set without HttpOnly flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.

WASC Id

 		13

Low (Warning) Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Product?categoryId=8
Parameter
Attack
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

 		https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

WASC Id

 		14

Low (Warning) X-Content-Type-Options header missing

Description

The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Product?categoryId=8
Parameter
Attack
Other information

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages. If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

Reference

WASC Id

Low (Warning) Content Security Policy (CSP) Header Not Set

Description

Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks, including Cross Site Scripting (XSS) and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a standard HTTP header that allows website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Product?categoryId=8
Parameter
Attack
Other information

Solution

Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to set Content Security Policy headers.

Reference

 		https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Security/CSP/Introducing_Content_Security_Policy https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Content_Security_Policy http://www.w3.org/TR/CSP/ http://w3c.github.io/webappsec/specs/content-security-policy/csp-specification.dev.html http://www.html5rocks.com/en/tutorials/security/content-security-policy/ http://caniuse.com/#feat=contentsecuritypolicy

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

Reference

 		www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

WASC Id

 		13

Low (Warning) Cookie set without secure flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Product?categoryId=5
Parameter
ASP.NET_SessionId=4zrued5rvyswbakn1b5vecs5; path=/
Attack
Other information

Solution

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

Reference

 		http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

 		13

Low (Warning) Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Product?categoryId=5
Parameter
Attack
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

 		https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

WASC Id

 		14

Low (Warning) X-Content-Type-Options header missing

Description

The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Product?categoryId=5
Parameter
Attack
Other information

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages. If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

Reference

WASC Id

Low (Warning) Server Leaks Information via "X-Powered-By" HTTP Response Header Field(s)

Description

The web/application server is leaking information via one or more "X-Powered-By" HTTP response headers. Access to such information may facilitate attackers identifying other frameworks/components your web application is reliant upon and the vulnerabilities such components may be subject to.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Product?categoryId=5
Parameter
Attack
Other information

Solution

Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to suppress "X-Powered-By" headers.

Reference

 		http://blogs.msdn.com/b/varunm/archive/2013/04/23/remove-unwanted-http-response-headers.aspx http://www.troyhunt.com/2012/02/shhh-dont-let-your-response-headers.html

WASC Id

 		13

Low (Warning) Content Security Policy (CSP) Header Not Set

Description

Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks, including Cross Site Scripting (XSS) and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a standard HTTP header that allows website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Product?categoryId=5
Parameter
Attack
Other information

Solution

Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to set Content Security Policy headers.

Reference

 		https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Security/CSP/Introducing_Content_Security_Policy https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Content_Security_Policy http://www.w3.org/TR/CSP/ http://w3c.github.io/webappsec/specs/content-security-policy/csp-specification.dev.html http://www.html5rocks.com/en/tutorials/security/content-security-policy/ http://caniuse.com/#feat=contentsecuritypolicy

WASC Id

Low (Warning) Server Leaks Version Information via "Server" HTTP Response Header Field

Description

The web/application server is leaking version information via the "Server" HTTP response header. Access to such information may facilitate attackers identifying other vulnerabilities your web/application server is subject to.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Product?categoryId=5
Parameter
Attack
Other information

Solution

Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to suppress the "Server" header or provide generic details.

Reference

 		http://httpd.apache.org/docs/current/mod/core.html#servertokens http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ff648552.aspx#ht_urlscan_007 http://blogs.msdn.com/b/varunm/archive/2013/04/23/remove-unwanted-http-response-headers.aspx http://www.troyhunt.com/2012/02/shhh-dont-let-your-response-headers.html

WASC Id

 		13

Low (Warning) Strict-Transport-Security Header Not Set

Description

HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) is a web security policy mechanism whereby a web server declares that complying user agents (such as a web browser) are to interact with it using only secure HTTPS connections (i.e. HTTP layered over TLS/SSL). HSTS is an IETF standards track protocol and is specified in RFC 6797.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Product?categoryId=5
Parameter
Attack
Other information

Solution

Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to enforce Strict-Transport-Security.

Reference

 		https://www.owasp.org/index.php/HTTP_Strict_Transport_Security https://www.owasp.org/index.php/List_of_useful_HTTP_headers http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTTP_Strict_Transport_Security http://caniuse.com/stricttransportsecurity http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6797

WASC Id

Low (Warning) Incomplete or no cache-control and pragma HTTPHeader set

Description

The cache-control and pragma HTTPHeader have not been set properly allowing the browser and proxies to cache content

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Product?categoryId=6
Parameter
private, s-maxage=0
Attack
Other information

Solution

Whenever possible ensure the cache-control HTTPHeader is set with no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate, private, and the pragma HTTPHeader is set with no-cache.

Reference

 		https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Session_Management_Cheat_Sheet#Web_Content_Caching

WASC Id

Low (Warning) Cookie set without secure flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Product?categoryId=6
Parameter
ASP.NET_SessionId=1ztz5zby4fpcdulya3rdngao; path=/
Attack
Other information

Solution

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

Reference

 		http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

 		13

Low (Warning) Cookie set without HttpOnly flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Product?categoryId=6
Parameter
ASP.NET_SessionId=1ztz5zby4fpcdulya3rdngao; path=/
Attack
Other information

Solution

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

Reference

 		www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

WASC Id

 		13

Low (Warning) Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Product?categoryId=6
Parameter
Attack
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

 		https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

WASC Id

 		14

Low (Warning) X-Content-Type-Options header missing

Description

The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Product?categoryId=6
Parameter
Attack
Other information

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages. If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

Reference

Low (Warning) Content Security Policy (CSP) Header Not Set

Description

Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks, including Cross Site Scripting (XSS) and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a standard HTTP header that allows website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Product?categoryId=6

https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Product?categoryId=3
Parameter
Attack
Other information

Solution

Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to suppress the "Server" header or provide generic details.

Reference

 		http://httpd.apache.org/docs/current/mod/core.html#servertokens http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ff648552.aspx#ht_urlscan_007 http://blogs.msdn.com/b/varunm/archive/2013/04/23/remove-unwanted-http-response-headers.aspx http://www.troyhunt.com/2012/02/shhh-dont-let-your-response-headers.html

WASC Id

 		13

Low (Warning) Strict-Transport-Security Header Not Set

Description

HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) is a web security policy mechanism whereby a web server declares that complying user agents (such as a web browser) are to interact with it using only secure HTTPS connections (i.e. HTTP layered over TLS/SSL). HSTS is an IETF standards track protocol and is specified in RFC 6797.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Product?categoryId=3
Parameter
Attack
Other information

Solution

Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to enforce Strict-Transport-Security.

Reference

 		https://www.owasp.org/index.php/HTTP_Strict_Transport_Security https://www.owasp.org/index.php/List_of_useful_HTTP_headers http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTTP_Strict_Transport_Security http://caniuse.com/stricttransportsecurity http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6797

WASC Id

Low (Warning) Server Leaks Information via "X-Powered-By" HTTP Response Header Field(s)

Description

The web/application server is leaking information via one or more "X-Powered-By" HTTP response headers. Access to such information may facilitate attackers identifying other frameworks/components your web application is reliant upon and the vulnerabilities such components may be subject to.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Product?categoryId=3
Parameter
Attack
Other information

Solution

Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to suppress "X-Powered-By" headers.

Reference

 		http://blogs.msdn.com/b/varunm/archive/2013/04/23/remove-unwanted-http-response-headers.aspx http://www.troyhunt.com/2012/02/shhh-dont-let-your-response-headers.html

WASC Id

 		13

Low (Warning) Incomplete or no cache-control and pragma HTTPHeader set

Description

The cache-control and pragma HTTPHeader have not been set properly allowing the browser and proxies to cache content

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Product?categoryId=2
Parameter
private, s-maxage=0
Attack
Other information

Solution

Whenever possible ensure the cache-control HTTPHeader is set with no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate, private, and the pragma HTTPHeader is set with no-cache.

Reference

 		https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Session_Management_Cheat_Sheet#Web_Content_Caching

WASC Id

Low (Warning) Cookie set without secure flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Product?categoryId=2
Parameter
ASP.NET_SessionId=bcyxhoc2lluduz1b0imw55x4; path=/
Attack
Other information

Solution

Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted tunnel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

Reference

 		http://www.owasp.org/index.php/Testing_for_cookies_attributes_(OWASP-SM-002)

WASC Id

 		13

Low (Warning) Cookie set without HttpOnly flag

Description

A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Product?categoryId=2
Parameter
ASP.NET_SessionId=bcyxhoc2lluduz1b0imw55x4; path=/
Attack
Other information

Solution

Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

Reference

 		www.owasp.org/index.php/HttpOnly

WASC Id

 		13

Low (Warning) Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Product?categoryId=2
Parameter
Attack
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

 		https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

WASC Id

 		14

Low (Warning) X-Content-Type-Options header missing

Description

The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Product?categoryId=2
Parameter
Attack
Other information

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages. If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

Reference

WASC Id

Low (Warning) Content Security Policy (CSP) Header Not Set

Description

Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks, including Cross Site Scripting (XSS) and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a standard HTTP header that allows website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Product?categoryId=2
Parameter
Attack
Other information

Solution

Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to set Content Security Policy headers.

Reference

 		https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Security/CSP/Introducing_Content_Security_Policy https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Content_Security_Policy http://www.w3.org/TR/CSP/ http://w3c.github.io/webappsec/specs/content-security-policy/csp-specification.dev.html http://www.html5rocks.com/en/tutorials/security/content-security-policy/ http://caniuse.com/#feat=contentsecuritypolicy

WASC Id

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Product?categoryId=2
Parameter
Attack
Other information

Solution

 		http://httpd.apache.org/docs/current/mod/core.html#servertokens http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ff648552.aspx#ht_urlscan_007 http://blogs.msdn.com/b/varunm/archive/2013/04/23/remove-unwanted-http-response-headers.aspx http://www.troyhunt.com/2012/02/shhh-dont-let-your-response-headers.html

 		13

Low (Warning) Cookie set without HttpOnly flag

Description

WASC Id

 		13

Low (Warning) Web Browser XSS Protection Not Enabled

Description

Web Browser XSS Protection is not enabled, or is disabled by the configuration of the 'X-XSS-Protection' HTTP response header on the web server

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Product?categoryId=1
Parameter
Attack
Other information
The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header allows the web server to enable or disable the web browser's XSS protection mechanism. The following values would attempt to enable it: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block X-XSS-Protection: 1; report=http://www.example.com/xss The following values would disable it: X-XSS-Protection: 0 The X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header is currently supported on Internet Explorer, Chrome and Safari (WebKit). Note that this alert is only raised if the response body could potentially contain an XSS payload (with a text-based content type, with a non-zero length).

Solution

Ensure that the web browser's XSS filter is enabled, by setting the X-XSS-Protection HTTP response header to '1'.

Reference

 		https://www.owasp.org/index.php/XSS_(Cross_Site_Scripting)_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet https://blog.veracode.com/2014/03/guidelines-for-setting-security-headers/

WASC Id

 		14

Low (Warning) X-Content-Type-Options header missing

Description

The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Product?categoryId=1
Parameter
Attack
Other information

Solution

Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages. If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

Reference

Description

Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks, including Cross Site Scripting (XSS) and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a standard HTTP header that allows website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.

URL

This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Low (Warning) Server Leaks Information via "X-Powered-By" HTTP Response Header Field(s)

The web/application server is leaking information via one or more "X-Powered-By" HTTP response headers. Access to such information may facilitate attackers identifying other frameworks/components your web application is reliant upon and the vulnerabilities such components may be subject to.

Reference

 		http://blogs.msdn.com/b/varunm/archive/2013/04/23/remove-unwanted-http-response-headers.aspx http://www.troyhunt.com/2012/02/shhh-dont-let-your-response-headers.html

WASC Id

 		13

Informational (Warning) X-Frame-Options header not set

Description

X-Frame-Options header is not included in the HTTP response to protect against 'ClickJacking' attacks

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp
Parameter
Attack
Other information

Solution

Most modern Web browsers support the X-Frame-Options HTTP header. Ensure it's set on all web pages returned by your site (if you expect the page to be framed only by pages on your server (e.g. it's part of a FRAMESET) then you'll want to use SAMEORIGIN, otherwise if you never expect the page to be framed, you should use DENY. ALLOW-FROM allows specific websites to frame the web page in supported web browsers).

Reference

 		http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ieinternals/archive/2010/03/30/combating-clickjacking-with-x-frame-options.aspx?Redirected=true

WASC Id

Informational (Warning) X-Frame-Options header not set

Description

X-Frame-Options header is not included in the HTTP response to protect against 'ClickJacking' attacks

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Account/Login?ReturnUrl=%2fSqliModernApp
Parameter
Attack
Other information

Solution

Most modern Web browsers support the X-Frame-Options HTTP header. Ensure it's set on all web pages returned by your site (if you expect the page to be framed only by pages on your server (e.g. it's part of a FRAMESET) then you'll want to use SAMEORIGIN, otherwise if you never expect the page to be framed, you should use DENY. ALLOW-FROM allows specific websites to frame the web page in supported web browsers).

Reference

 		http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ieinternals/archive/2010/03/30/combating-clickjacking-with-x-frame-options.aspx?Redirected=true

WASC Id

Informational (Warning) Base64 Disclosure

Description

Base64 encoded data was disclosed by the application/web server

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Account/Login?ReturnUrl=%2fSqliModernApp
Parameter
Attack
tjh7qaPlWZCRWFfXjZu25UnTwyKwE8UR200Bvn8mJPTX19CngZkcnTy9
Other information
8{YXWI"\x0013\x0011M\x0001&$\x001c<

Solution

Manually confirm that the Base64 data does not leak sensitive information, and that the data cannot be aggregated/used to exploit other vulnerabilities.

Reference

 		https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Top_10_2013-A6-Sensitive_Data_Exposure http://projects.webappsec.org/w/page/13246936/Information%20Leakage

Informational (Warning) Base64 Disclosure

Base64 encoded data was disclosed by the application/web server

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Account/Login?ReturnUrl=%2fSqliModernApp
Parameter
Attack
tjh7qaPlWZCRWFfXjZu25UnTwyKwE8UR200Bvn8mJPTX19CngZkcnTy9_oAl2eYugechS_QiZZNuDtT9FpF8cDrZoREEWsy7PxFuGv2tfUIa2BkbtLKFiS6615iNDbCDNwJ4RkDWNHM8-h1AT67Ubw2
Other information
8{YXWI"\x0013\x0011M\x0001&$\x001c<%.!K"en\x000e\x0016|p:\x0011\x0004Z?\x0011n\x001a}B\x001a\x0019\x001b. 7\x0002xF@4s<\x001d@O

Solution

Manually confirm that the Base64 data does not leak sensitive information, and that the data cannot be aggregated/used to exploit other vulnerabilities.

Reference

 		https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Top_10_2013-A6-Sensitive_Data_Exposure http://projects.webappsec.org/w/page/13246936/Information%20Leakage

m\x0002wh.\\x001a*\x000cN:\x0007\x0012Y\x0013Z\x001aM7(?\x0001:\x0008\x0001jo4\x0010\x0014Z46 \x0019\x0012q*\x0001mP_t~[\x0007zP$\ z{p/atei\x0005F{}6X\x000b\x0006E5

WASC Id

 		13

Informational (Warning) X-Frame-Options header not set

Description

X-Frame-Options header is not included in the HTTP response to protect against 'ClickJacking' attacks

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Content/site.css
Parameter
Attack
Other information

Solution

Most modern Web browsers support the X-Frame-Options HTTP header. Ensure it's set on all web pages returned by your site (if you expect the page to be framed only by pages on your server (e.g. it's part of a FRAMESET) then you'll want to use SAMEORIGIN, otherwise if you never expect the page to be framed, you should use DENY. ALLOW-FROM allows specific websites to frame the web page in supported web browsers).

Reference

 		http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ieinternals/archive/2010/03/30/combating-clickjacking-with-x-frame-options.aspx?Redirected=true

WASC Id

Informational (Warning) X-Frame-Options header not set

Description

X-Frame-Options header is not included in the HTTP response to protect against 'ClickJacking' attacks

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Scripts/modernizr-2.6.2.js
Parameter
Attack
Other information

Solution

Most modern Web browsers support the X-Frame-Options HTTP header. Ensure it's set on all web pages returned by your site (if you expect the page to be framed only by pages on your server (e.g. it's part of a FRAMESET) then you'll want to use SAMEORIGIN, otherwise if you never expect the page to be framed, you should use DENY. ALLOW-FROM allows specific websites to frame the web page in supported web browsers).

Reference

 		http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ieinternals/archive/2010/03/30/combating-clickjacking-with-x-frame-options.aspx?Redirected=true

Other information

WASC Id

 		13

Informational (Warning) Information disclosure - suspicious comments

Description

The response appears to contain suspicious comments which may help an attacker

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Scripts/modernizr-2.6.2.js
Parameter
Attack
Other information
// TODO :: make the prefixes more granular // TODO :: Add flag for hasownprop ? didn't last time // TODO :: add testDOMProps // legacy webkit syntax (FIXME: remove when syntax not in use anymore) // IE9 Running on Windows Server SKU can cause an exception to be thrown, bug #224 // todo: hypothetically we could be doing an array of tests and use a basic loop here.

Solution

Remove all comments that return information that may help an attacker and fix any underlying problems they refer to

Reference

 		https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Top_10_2013-A6-Sensitive_Data_Exposure http://projects.webappsec.org/w/page/13246936/Information%20Leakage

WASC Id

 		13

Informational (Warning) X-Frame-Options header not set

Description

X-Frame-Options header is not included in the HTTP response to protect against 'ClickJacking' attacks

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Product/AdvSearch
Parameter
Attack
Other information

Solution

Most modern Web browsers support the X-Frame-Options HTTP header. Ensure it's set on all web pages returned by your site (if you expect the page to be framed only by pages on your server (e.g. it's part of a FRAMESET) then you'll want to use SAMEORIGIN, otherwise if you never expect the page to be framed, you should use DENY. ALLOW-FROM allows specific websites to frame the web page in supported web browsers).

Reference

 		http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ieinternals/archive/2010/03/30/combating-clickjacking-with-x-frame-options.aspx?Redirected=true

\x001dzeJsdWupb] \x0017D8\x0001\x0011@\x0014a6We\x001a\x0011\x0015#F6m>\x0019ni?3]r\x000e jch \x0018\x001e\x0011w{} H SG\x001d\x001dW\x0018\x001eU5

Solution

Manually confirm that the Base64 data does not leak sensitive information, and that the data cannot be aggregated/used to exploit other vulnerabilities.

Reference

 		https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Top_10_2013-A6-Sensitive_Data_Exposure http://projects.webappsec.org/w/page/13246936/Information%20Leakage

WASC Id

 		13

Informational (Warning) X-Frame-Options header not set

Description

X-Frame-Options header is not included in the HTTP response to protect against 'ClickJacking' attacks

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Quack/Now
Parameter
Attack
Other information

Solution

Most modern Web browsers support the X-Frame-Options HTTP header. Ensure it's set on all web pages returned by your site (if you expect the page to be framed only by pages on your server (e.g. it's part of a FRAMESET) then you'll want to use SAMEORIGIN, otherwise if you never expect the page to be framed, you should use DENY. ALLOW-FROM allows specific websites to frame the web page in supported web browsers).

Reference

 		http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ieinternals/archive/2010/03/30/combating-clickjacking-with-x-frame-options.aspx?Redirected=true

Description

URL

Parameter
Attack
Other information

Solution

Most modern Web browsers support the X-Frame-Options HTTP header. Ensure it's set on all web pages returned by your site (if you expect the page to be framed only by pages on your server (e.g. it's part of a FRAMESET) then you'll want to use SAMEORIGIN, otherwise if you never expect the page to be framed, you should use DENY. ALLOW-FROM allows specific websites to frame the web page in supported web browsers).

Reference

 		http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ieinternals/archive/2010/03/30/combating-clickjacking-with-x-frame-options.aspx?Redirected=true

ALLOW-FROM allows specific websites to frame the web page in supported web browsers).

 		http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ieinternals/archive/2010/03/30/combating-clickjacking-with-x-frame-options.aspx?Redirected=true

W\x000e:dqyt=\x001e$F\x0000=

Solution

Manually confirm that the Base64 data does not leak sensitive information, and that the data cannot be aggregated/used to exploit other vulnerabilities.

Reference

 		https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Top_10_2013-A6-Sensitive_Data_Exposure http://projects.webappsec.org/w/page/13246936/Information%20Leakage

WASC Id

 		13

WASC Id

 		13

Informational (Warning) X-Frame-Options header not set

Description

X-Frame-Options header is not included in the HTTP response to protect against 'ClickJacking' attacks

URL
https://sqli:8021/SqliModernApp/Product?categoryId=8
Parameter
Attack
Other information

Solution

Most modern Web browsers support the X-Frame-Options HTTP header. Ensure it's set on all web pages returned by your site (if you expect the page to be framed only by pages on your server (e.g. it's part of a FRAMESET) then you'll want to use SAMEORIGIN, otherwise if you never expect the page to be framed, you should use DENY. ALLOW-FROM allows specific websites to frame the web page in supported web browsers).

Reference

 		http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ieinternals/archive/2010/03/30/combating-clickjacking-with-x-frame-options.aspx?Redirected=true

WASC Id

Other information

ALLOW-FROM allows specific websites to frame the web page in supported web browsers).

 		http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ieinternals/archive/2010/03/30/combating-clickjacking-with-x-frame-options.aspx?Redirected=true
